thread.title: Three drug-trafficking newbies fail to fool cops
thread.title_full: Three drug-trafficking newbies fail to fool cops

title: Three drug-trafficking newbies fail to fool cops
text:
Thursday, 23 February 2017 Three drug-trafficking newbies fail to fool cops 
ALOR SETAR: They thought they could hoodwink the police, hiding their drugs in premium Chinese tea packaging and stashing them inside the cavities of their cars’ dashboard. 
But the police, who were on to them the whole time, were just waiting for them to cross the border. 
The three Malaysian men who tried to drive three cars loaded with 90kg of methamphetamine or syabu into Malaysia from Thailand never had a chance. 
Two of them were stopped at the Customs and Immigration Quarantine Complex in Padang Besar, Perlis. 
The third man only got as far as Changlun after entering through Bukit Kayu Hitam, before police stopped him on the road. 
Bukit Aman Narcotics Crime Investigation Department director Comm Datuk Seri Mohd Mokhtar Mohd Shariff said police considered the three men “newcomers” to the drug-trafficking business. 
They had “just begun”, he added when asked for details on the traffickers. 
The drugs, he said, had an estimated street value of RM6.3mil, came from the Golden Triangle and was meant for Malaysia and Indonesia. 
Speaking at a press conference in the state police headquarters here, Comm Mohd Mokhtar said the arrests were made possible through cooperation between Bukit Aman’s Special Tactical Intelligence Narcotics Group (STING) and Royal Thai Police’s Police Narcotics Suppression Bureau (PNSB). 
l Feb 27, and Comm Mohd Mokhtar said one of them was wanted by the police while another tested positive for methamphetamine. 
“It is through our proactive and close cooperation with our Thai counterparts that we can fight the war against drugs,” he added. 
He also announced that from Jan 1 to Feb 16, some 26,925 people were arrested nationwide for drug-related offences. 
They included 22,182 locals and 1,039 foreigners, while drugs worth RM17.75mil, five pistols and 315 rounds of ammunition were seized. 
He said the synthetic drugs confiscated were syabu (166.92kg), ketamine (8.81kg), ecstasy pills (35,395), Yaba pills (52,015) and Erimine 5 pills (51,273). 
The traditional drugs included cannabis (237.26kg) and heroin (60.85kg). 
“We also seized RM22.19mil in properties and valuables.” 
Also present were Kedah police chief Comm Datuk Asri Yusoff, PNSB chief commander Major-General Soonthorn Chalermkiat, the bureau’s narcotics intelligence commander Major-General Chayapoj Hasunaha and drug interdiction commander Major-General Tanai Apichatsanee.
